messages.text: FWIW, I don't think it is that important to recognize, it's fairly obvious what is meant with politics here and it should be easy to separate that from the policies the julia community itself implement.

elements.text: FWIW, I don't think it is that important to recognize, it's fairly obvious what is meant with politics here and it should be easy to separate that from the policies the julia community itself implement.

messages.text: It's among the same lines as saying "it is important to recognize that not allowing intolerant people is a limit of tolerance". Technically true, but irrelevant in practice.

elements.text: It's among the same lines as saying "it is important to recognize that not allowing intolerant people is a limit of tolerance". Technically true, but irrelevant in practice.

messages.text:
Yeah I was debating posting that comment. It's probably obvious for you, but for people who never think about politics that way (me as a teenager,  for instance) I think it's useful.

I'm aware that I am coming dangerously close to the edge of the "no politics" line here, but I also want to say that the statement "it is important to recognize that not allowing intolerant people is a limit of tolerance" is not the same. Discussing politics benefits marginalized people who stand to liberate themselves from changing the current politics.

So what I mean is, banning "politics" is really an implicit endorsement of the status quo and the people that benefit from maintaining it. If that is obvious to you, great, but I don't think it is for everyone.

elements.text:

Discussing politics benefits marginalized people who stand to liberate themselves from changing the current politics.

So what I mean is, banning "politics" is really an implicit endorsement of the status quo and the people that benefit from maintaining it. If that is obvious to you, great, but I don't think it is for everyone.

messages.text:
The reason this slack community has policies against political discussion is that the discussions that were happening were becoming increasingly unproductive, nasty and unwelcoming. 

The discussions happening had very little if any benefit to the wider world, but had a palpably negative effect on the health of the community and how welcoming it was to new members.

elements.text:
The reason this slack community has policies against political discussion is that the discussions that were happening were becoming increasingly unproductive, nasty and unwelcoming. 

The discussions happening had very little if any benefit to the wider world, but had a palpably negative effect on the health of the community and how welcoming it was to new members.

messages.text: There's a very specific kind of "politics" that I (personally) don't care for here, not least of which because I have no influence over it: US/any kind of government related politics. Not wanting to talk about things I can't influence at all is not the same as endorsing them.

elements.text: There's a very specific kind of "politics" that I (personally) don't care for here, not least of which because I have no influence over it: US/any kind of government related politics. Not wanting to talk about things I can't influence at all is not the same as endorsing them.

messages.text: "Politics" as it relates to how we, as a community, want to do things for us, is obviously not the in the same vein here - that doesn't mean that we have to bring in that other kind of politics though.

elements.text: "Politics" as it relates to how we, as a community, want to do things for us, is obviously not the in the same vein here - that doesn't mean that we have to bring in that other kind of politics though.

messages.text: Yes I agree, I was clarifying since I felt that <@U67D54KS8> did not properly characterize my comment in his reply.

elements.text: Yes I agree, I was clarifying since I felt that
did not properly characterize my comment in his reply.

messages.text: Well, no one is suggesting that you cannot discuss politics outside of the Julia platforms. It's not like the policy means that Kristoffer cannot endorse Trump on twitter for example. It just means that "our" (collectively as Julia users) slack/discourse is not the place to do it.

elements.text: Well, no one is suggesting that you cannot discuss politics outside of the Julia platforms. It's not like the policy means that Kristoffer cannot endorse Trump on twitter for example. It just means that "our" (collectively as Julia users) slack/discourse is not the place to do it.

elements.text: Giving a 20ish minute "Consider Julia" talk in Spanish tomorrow, recording my prez tonight

attachments.title: "Considera Julia", 20 min Julia pitch in Spanish
attachments.text: Hello all! ¡Saludos banda! I will be giving a brief 20 min-ish talk tomorrow in Spanish called “Considering Julia”. It will be in Spanish, the link is below. I will be pre-recording a longer version (á la JuliaCon) so that I can talk about the things I want without feeling rushed :smiley: This was in part facilitated by @categulario (not yet here) and @xalapacode, a Mexican local coding org. I will post a link to the youtube recording here once I’m done.

messages.text: Has anyone in any ecosystem done an analysis on “mean time to ‘we’?”

elements.text: Has anyone in any ecosystem done an analysis on “mean time to ‘we’?”

messages.text: that is, how long does it take someone to start talking in the third person plural?

elements.text: that is, how long does it take someone to start talking in the third person plural?

messages.text: I consciously do it almost immediately for open source stuff.

elements.text: I consciously do it almost immediately for open source stuff.

messages.text: At the point I am openning an issue, I say things like: _"X is hard to use. Can we add a option for Y, or should we improve the docs ..."_

elements.text: At the point I am openning an issue, I say things like: _"X is hard to use. Can we add a option for Y, or should we improve the docs ..."_

messages.text: I think it's good because it is non-confrontational. I am not saying "your thing is hard to use", I am making it clear that I want to collaborate to find a solution

elements.text: I think it's good because it is non-confrontational. I am not saying "your thing is hard to use", I am making it clear that I want to collaborate to find a solution

messages.text: I personally feel it comes off a bit odd when someone brand new to a community starts "we"-ing straight away, especially when it is combined with strong opinions about moving the project in certain ways.

elements.text: I personally feel it comes off a bit odd when someone brand new to a community starts "we"-ing straight away, especially when it is combined with strong opinions about moving the project in certain ways.

messages.text: I always feel like I need to clarify the "we", am I talking as a member of the community, the JuliaLab, which subsection of the community (we === GPU folks, we === Julia Base) so I stick to I fairly often. I think ;)

elements.text: I always feel like I need to clarify the "we", am I talking as a member of the community, the JuliaLab, which subsection of the community (we === GPU folks, we === Julia Base) so I stick to I fairly often. I think ;)

messages.text: I would be  careful to put weight on these things, that’s quite influenced by mother tongue, strata etc

elements.text: I would be  careful to put weight on these things, that’s quite influenced by mother tongue, strata etc

messages.text: For example I often hear “mi mama” (my mother) in Spanish even if one sibling talks to another sibling, which sounds very weird when your own language requires the use of “our mother” in this situation

messages.text: This message was deleted.

I'm afraid the replies to the hackernews comment (in the 1.6 release post) pointing out julia is not top on the list in <https://github.com/kostya/benchmarks> weren't entirely accurate... Too often benchmarks with questionable julia timings include compilation time, but in this case the benchmark is reasonably fair (timing starts halfway in a function by sending some message through a socket, and sometimes a verification test is run before the benchmark). I (and some others) jumped a bit too quickly to the conclusion that the benchmark was unfair/skew, and one comment which correctly points that out got downvoted to oblivion :sweat_smile:

elements.text: We are live:

messages.text: <@U67461GUB>, i just want to mention that ML is not the same as autodiff. gradient heuristic employed in neural networks or deeplearning for prediction or classification is just one of the many techniques in machine learning. for tabular data which are common datasets in ML, autodiff heuristics are always beaten by SVM or Ensemble methods such as xgboost or randomforest. a lot of ML problems are tabular data so i just want to correct the notion that ML is equivalent to autodiff and by having autodiff part of julia language implies it is solving much of ML. a lot of optimization problems are not differentiable too and can be addressed better by gradient-free methods. great talk by the way but i find the talk on autodiff implying that all ML problems to be solvable by autodiff as not right. model selection is important in ML and gradient method is just one of the hundreds of ML methods. it is not always the case that gradient method will be the optimal solution to many ML problems. i don’t want people to think that whenever they have a prediction or classification task, they will not try other ML models and just use gradient-based or autodiff-based algo such as ANN or deeplearning. please do model selection by trying other ML models instead of just one. this is a basic principle in ML modeling: perform model selection, and hyperparameter optimization later... and of course there is information criterion to be aware of in modeling too. autodiff solution for ML is an oversimplification of what the real challenge in ML modeling. autodiff has tendency to either overfit or underfit the solution because it is a greedy heuristic and hard to optimize due to its large number of parameters and very sensitive to its initial parameters.

elements.text: , i just want to mention that ML is not the same as autodiff. gradient heuristic employed in neural networks or deeplearning for prediction or classification is just one of the many techniques in machine learning. for tabular data which are common datasets in ML, autodiff heuristics are always beaten by SVM or Ensemble methods such as xgboost or randomforest. a lot of ML problems are tabular data so i just want to correct the notion that ML is equivalent to autodiff and by having autodiff part of julia language implies it is solving much of ML. a lot of optimization problems are not differentiable too and can be addressed better by gradient-free methods. great talk by the way but i find the talk on autodiff implying that all ML problems to be solvable by autodiff as not right. model selection is important in ML and gradient method is just one of the hundreds of ML methods. it is not always the case that gradient method will be the optimal solution to many ML problems. i don’t want people to think that whenever they have a prediction or classification task, they will not try other ML models and just use gradient-based or autodiff-based algo such as ANN or deeplearning. please do model selection by trying other ML models instead of just one. this is a basic principle in ML modeling: perform model selection, and hyperparameter optimization later... and of course there is information criterion to be aware of in modeling too. autodiff solution for ML is an oversimplification of what the real challenge in ML modeling. autodiff has tendency to either overfit or underfit the solution because it is a greedy heuristic and hard to optimize due to its large number of parameters and very sensitive to its initial parameters.

messages.text: All good points.

messages.text: Linear regression, XGBoost, lasso gradient and dl.  Doesn't that cover like 98% of real world problems?

elements.text: Linear regression, XGBoost, lasso gradient and dl.  Doesn't that cover like 98% of real world problems?

messages.text: For most of the rest, bayesian ML. If you're doing continuous parameters, again that uses autodiff

elements.text: For most of the rest, bayesian ML. If you're doing continuous parameters, again that uses autodiff
